As an AI language model, I would be happy to suggest some more challenging hikes in the Rutland area for you:

1. Killington Peak Trail: This is a challenging hike with significant elevation gain. It takes you to the top of Killington Peak, the second-highest peak in Vermont at 4,241 feet.

2. White Rocks Trail: This is a 6.2-mile loop trail that is rated as difficult. It offers challenging steep inclines and rocky terrain, but it rewards hikers with breathtaking views of the Green Mountains.

3. Mount Equinox Trail: This is a 6.3-mile out-and-back trail that is rated as difficult. The trail offers a steep ascent to the summit of Mount Equinox, and you'll be rewarded with stunning views of the surrounding area.

4. Deer Leap Trail: This is a 4.4-mile out-and-back trail that is rated as moderate to difficult. The trail offers stunning views of Sherburne Pass and Pico Peak.

Please note that these hikes are challenging, and you should come prepared with proper equipment, including sturdy footwear, water, and snacks. It's also important to check the weather and trail conditions before embarking on your hike.

Great to hear you're excited about these hikes! Here are some tips and recommendations to help you prepare:

1. Gear: Wear comfortable and sturdy hiking boots, dress in layers, and bring plenty of water, snacks, a headlamp, and a first aid kit. You might also want to consider bringing trekking poles, sunscreen, and bug spray.

2. Training: Depending on your fitness level, it may be a good idea to start with some less challenging hikes and gradually work up to longer and more difficult ones. You can also incorporate exercises such as lunges, squats, and cardio to build strength and endurance. 

3. Research: Before you go on any hike, do some research about the trail, including its length, elevation gain, and difficulty level. Review trail maps and check weather conditions and trail conditions. 

4. Safety: Be sure to let someone know your itinerary and expected return time before you head out on the trail. Stick to marked trails, avoid hiking alone, and watch out for weather changes, especially lightning storms.

Following these tips can help ensure a safe and enjoyable experience. Good luck and have fun on your hikes!

Sure, here are a few more outdoor activities to consider while you're in the Rutland area:

1. Lake Bomoseen: This is the largest lake entirely within Vermont's borders and offers a variety of water-based activities, including swimming, boating, and fishing.

2. Vermont State Parks: The Rutland area is home to several picturesque state parks, including Gifford Woods State Park, Silver Lake State Park, and Bomoseen State Park. These parks offer hiking, camping, fishing, swimming, and other recreational opportunities.

3. Mountain Biking: The Green Mountains offer excellent mountain biking trails, including the Pine Hill Park Trail System and the Killington Bike Park. These trails provide a variety of levels of difficulty, so be sure to do your research and select a trail that matches your ability level.

4. Golfing: If you're a golfer, you're in luck! Rutland is home to several top-rated golf courses, including Green Mountain National Golf Course and Neshobe Golf Club.

5. Skiing and Snowboarding: When winter rolls around, skiing and snowboarding are popular activities in the area, with resorts such as Killington, Pico, and Okemo Mountain Resort offering a variety of slopes and trails for all skill levels.

Regardless of which activity you choose, the Rutland area is sure to provide an unforgettable outdoor experience.
